meta.content: Macmillan/McGraw-Hill Treasures: A Reading/Language Arts Program

level1.p: This accessible media has been made available to people with bona fide disabilities that affect reading. This notice tells you about restrictions on the use of this accessible media, which could be a book, a periodical, or other content.

level2.p: This notice is not part of the copyrighted work, which begins below after the phrase "Begin Content".

Bookshare distributes this accessible media under restrictions set forth either in copyright law or in an agreement with the copyright owner. If you are not a person with a print disability, or an agency serving people with print disabilities, you should not use this accessible media and should destroy this content. You are not allowed to redistribute content derived from this accessible media to anybody else, with one exception: we allow hardcopy Braille books prepared from Accessible Media to be provided to other blind people.
Access to accessible media through Bookshare is a valuable right and privilege. Protect this access for the print disabled community by complying with these restrictions!

You, your parents, or your school (or agency) signed a Bookshare agreement. For the full text of the current version of the Member Agreements, please visit www.bookshare.org/Agreements. This information in this accessible media file does not in any way change the terms of your Agreement with Bookshare.

level2.h2: Limitation of Liability; Indemnity by User
level2.p: Most authors and publishers do not have control over the content available through Bookshare. By downloading and using this material, you agree that neither Bookshare nor the authors or original publishers of the materials shall be financially responsible for any loss or damage to you or any third parties caused by the failure or malfunction of the Bookshare Web Site (www.bookshare.org) or because of any inaccuracy or lack of completeness of any content that you download from the Web Site.

BOOKSHARE, AND THE AUTHORS, PUBLISHERS AND COPYRIGHT OWNERS OF THE MATERIALS, SHALL NOT IN ANY CASE BE LIABLE FOR DIRECT, INDIRECT, SPECIAL, INCIDENTAL OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES, WHETHER BASED ON CONTRACT, TORT OR ANY OTHER LEGAL THEORY, IN CONNECTION WITH OR ARISING OUT OF THE FURNISHING OF CONTENT, THE FUNCTIONING OF THE WEB SITE, OR ANY OTHER ASPECT OF YOUR USE OF THE WEB SITE AND THE CONTENTS PROVIDED HEREUNDER.

You agree to indemnify and hold Bookshare and Benetech, the Web Site provider, harmless from any liability, loss, cost, damage or expense, including reasonable attorney's fees, that result from any claim made by any author, publisher or copyright owner that you, or any one acquiring copies of copyrighted materials downloaded from the Web Site through you, is not print disabled or otherwise entitled to download and use the digital materials from the Bookshare Web Site. This indemnity includes any claims arising out of any breach of your obligations under your Member Agreement, whether by reason of misuse, negligence or otherwise.

level2.h2: Permitted Use; Limited Waiver of Privacy Principles and Laws
level2.p: You are permitted under this restricted license to use this digital copy for your own personal use. However, any further reproduction, distribution, or any commercial usage requires the express, prior consent of the copyright holder.

This material contains digital watermarks and fingerprints designed to identify this material as a Bookshare digital material that was specifically downloaded by you. It is generally illegal to delete or modify these watermarks and fingerprints, as well as being in violation of the terms of your Member Agreement. Your Member Agreement expressly authorizes us to include these security devices, solely for this use, as an express exception to current and future privacy laws relating to protection of personal information data. Should any future privacy law or regulation preclude the use of this personal data for purposes of tracking the downloading and use of these materials and enforcing the limitations of relevant copyright law or the Member Agreement, your right to use these materials will terminate on the effective date of any such law or regulation.
This material was downloaded by Rom Srinivasan and is digitally fingerprinted in the manner described above.
Bookshare is interested in improving book quality over time, if you can help us by providing any book quality feedback, we'll work hard to make those changes and republish the books.

sidebar.p: How does Keisha feel about being away from home?

level1.p: Printed in the United States of America

imggroup.prodnote: <![CDATA[A drawing of a small sea turtle.]]>

li.lic: Chapter 2 The Trip to the Island

level1.p: Keisha's mom sat up. She had been very sick. Now she was getting better. Keisha could see that her mother still seemed tired.

img.alt: a sick mother lying in bed with a girl beside her

imggroup.prodnote: <![CDATA[Keisha's mother lays in bed, while Keisha kneels on the floor next to her, and holds her hand. ]]>

level1.p: "I must rest in bed a while longer," she said. "Dad has to go back to his job. Aunt Louise will care for you over the vacation."
Aunt Louise had always visited them each year on her annual vacation.
"Aunt Louise can't come here. You must go to visit her this time," said Mom.
"Doesn't Aunt Louise live on a tropical island now?" Keisha asked.
"Yes, she works for a bank on Grand Cayman Island in the Caribbean," her mom said.
"Why did she move so far away?" Keisha asked.
It's a very good job," her mom said. "She has good skills, and she will probably get a raise soon."
"I won't like it there," Keisha said. "It's much too far away."

img.alt: a young girl dreaming of her aunt

imggroup.prodnote: <![CDATA[Keisha stands in her living room, thinking about a woman who is dressed in office clothes and sitting at a desk, but behind her are palm trees and the ocean.]]>

level1.h1: Chapter 2 The Trip to the Island
level1.p: Keisha liked the plane ride. She sat by a window, so she could see the land below.
Then she saw big white clouds. Before she knew it, the plane had landed.
Keisha walked down the plane's center aisle. A flight attendant joined her. Together they walked into the airport.
Aunt Louise was waiting by the gate. She showed the attendant her driver's license. It was proof that she was the person Keisha was supposed to meet.

img.alt: an airplane, a lady and a girl at the airport

imggroup.prodnote: <![CDATA[Aunt Louise reaches out to hug Keisha at the airstrip, with the airplane sitting behind them. ]]>

level1.p: Aunt Louise's car seemed odd to Keisha. The steering wheel looked wrong.
Aunt Louise saw Keisha's puzzled look. "Our cars here are like the cars in England," she said. "There is something else different too. We drive on the left side of the road."

img.alt: a lady and a girl inside the car

imggroup.prodnote: <![CDATA[Aunt Louise drives her car while Keisha sits in the back seat looking out the window, and smiling.]]>

level1.p: On the drive to Aunt Louise's home, Keisha looked out at the island. It had tall trees. The sea was a lovely blue. Still, Keisha wanted to go home.
The next day Aunt Louise taught Keisha to swim under the water. Keisha saw some amazing fish. Some had yellow stripes. Some were bright blue. Keisha still longed for home though.
After a few days, her aunt said, "I must go back to work soon. My friend Jill will come by when I go to the bank."
Keisha nodded politely. She was not happy about being taken care of by a stranger.

img.alt: a girl and an adult woman on the beach

imggroup.prodnote: <![CDATA[Aunt Louise and Keisha enjoy the beach. Snorkeling goggles and fins lay nearby and Keisha walks on the beach in her fins.]]>

level1.p: In a few days, Jill came by with her son Ted. Ted was the same age as Keisha.
They took Keisha to the island's turtle farm. Ted showed her two giant sea turtles. "There are different kinds of sea turtles here," he said.
Keisha held a baby sea turtle. "They're so sweet and innocent," she said.

img.alt: a girl held a baby turtle with a boy in the turtle farm

imggroup.prodnote: <![CDATA[Keisha stands near a boy holding a little turtle. Several other turtles are in the water behind them.]]>

level1.p: Keisha learned that baby green sea turtles face many perils in the wild.
When the green sea turtles hatch, they crawl to the sea. There is potential danger everywhere. Seabirds often eat them. Sharks and other large fish will eat them too.
The islanders help the baby turtles. They take the nests to the farm.
The baby green sea turtles stay at the turtle farm for a year. Small tags are put on them. After that, they are released into the sea.
Keisha picked one of the babies out of its tank. She showed it to Ted.
"I'm like one of these turtles," she said. "Kind people are taking good care of me. These turtles are lucky, and so am I."

img.alt: a baby green sea turtle on the hands

imggroup.prodnote: <![CDATA[Keisha holds a little turtle in her hands.]]>

img.alt: a girl opened a box wrapped in paper inside a wooden sea turtle

imggroup.prodnote: <![CDATA[Ted and aunt Louise give Keisha a present. Inside the box is a turtle. Keisha has a huge smile on her face.]]>

level1.p: Finally it was time for Keisha to leave for home. Ted gave her a package covered in wrapping paper. "It wasn't expensive," he said, "but I hope it reminds you of us." The present was a wooden sea turtle.
Keisha hugged Ted. "I'm glad to go home," she said to him. "I'll also be glad to come back to visit. Now this island feels like it's my second home."

level2.p: Why do you think Keisha's attitude about her trip changed in the story? Use an Inference Chart to record clues and an inference. Then use the chart to summarize the story.

li.span: Look back at page 6. Why do you think a flight attendant stayed with Keisha when she got off the plane?
If you visited Grand Cayman Island, what would you enjoy doing?
Why do you think it is important for people to help save animals that are in danger? Explain.

sidebar.p: Pretend that you are a travel agent. You are trying to get people to come to a tropical island. Design a brochure telling people about the island. Name the island. Draw pictures, too.
Use the library to learn more about turtles. Find five turtle facts and share them with your classmates.
